Award.AwardTitle: Fully nonlinear geometric partial differential equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to develop fundamental analytic tools for fully nonlinear equations airing from problems in differential geometry. The first project will build on the PI's work with Dinew and Zhang which proved the interior Holder continuity of the second order derivative for the weak solution of complex Monge-Ampere equations. This estimate is essential in studying the Kahler metric whose potential is of weak regularity. The PI proposes to establish this regularity estimate under more optimal condition. Along this direction, the PI will also study some interior estimates for the complex Monge-Ampere type equations. In the second project, the PI is determined to extend his recent work with Wang about the Alexandrov-Bakelman-Pucci (ABP) estimate on general Riemannian manifolds. The PI will investigate more interesting applications of this ABP method that is not broadly exploited in geometric analysis yet. It is possible to apply this technique to study the first proposed project on the complex Monge-Ampere equations. The third project concerns the mean curvature flows for Lagrangian submanifolds with boundaries which is related to a boundary value problem of a fully nonlinear equation. If the analytic parts were well understood, it would provide a powerful tool to construct special Lagrangian submanifolds with boundaries and to study the existence of the area-preserving minimal maps between bounded domains.

This project aims at studying problems arising from differential geometry via fully nonlinear elliptic and parabolic equations. The goal is to better understand relations between geometric quantities and properties of these important geometric fully nonlinear equations. The innovative techniques developed in this proposal will lead to the solutions of important problems in geometry and enriching the existing theory of fully nonlinear partial differential equations in general. In the process, this work is having important consequences in both physics and applied sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF grant supported the PI's research in the field of geometric analysis, which is the study of problems of geometric nature using the tools of analysis and partial differential equations. The fundamental laws of physics are described, in the language of mathematics, by differential equations. Understanding the behavior of solutions to differential equations is the key to unraveling the mystery of the geometry and structure of the universe. The research aims to develop fundamental analytic tools for various geometric fully nonlinear partial differential equations and investigate the structures of ``special" solutions of the equations related to geometric quantities on manifolds. 

One of the main themes of the research which has been carried out is the solvability of complex Monge-Amp\`ere type equations. A particular equation of this type is the so-called Fu-Yau equation, deduced from the study of a generalized Strominger system. Strominger's original motivation was from super-string theories, and the system of equations he proposed in 1986, described the geometry of compactifications of heterotic superstrings with flux. Nevertheless, the system and its generalizations are also remarkable form the mathematical standpoint since they can be viewed as a generalization of Ricci-flat metrics on non-K\"ahler manifolds. Therefore, it is important to study the solvability of the Fu-Yau equation and the original Strominger system from all aspects. With the support from NSF grant, the PI and his coauthors developed some foundmental analytic tools and completely solved the Fu-Yau equations when the slope parameter is negative. Consequently, the authors provided the first non-K\"ahler solution for the generalized Strominger system proposed by Fu and Yau. The PI also has made important progress for the slope parameter positive case, for which, he reduced the solvability problem to the validity of a non-degeneracy estimate. Aiming to develop analytical methods for solving the original Strominger system on general Calabi-Yau three manifolds, the PI and his coauthors also devised a new flow approach - anomaly flow. Important progress has been made for the flow on two model cases: one is the flow with zero slope parameter, while the other is the flow on the Goldstein-Prokushikin ansatz. These two cases will serve as good guide for the PI's future studies on the anomaly flow with full generality. 

Another main strand of the research that has been performed is the study of the so-called Alexandrov uniqueness theorems.  In 1950's, Alexandrov proved that any closed embedded hypersurface of constant mean curvature in Euclidean space must be a round sphere. There is a vast literature on generalizations of this theorem to various ambient manifolds. The PI was particularly interested in analogues of this theorem with two important new features, motivated by general relativity: codimension two submanifolds are considered instead of hypersurfaces, and the ambiant manifold is Lorentzian. In a work collaborated with Wang, the PI overcome the difficulties caused by the double normal directions by introducing the notion of {\it mixed higher order mean curvature} and establish Minkowski formulae for codimension two submanifolds in spacetimes. Based on these new ingredients, the PI proved the Alexandrov type theorems for spacelike submanifolds with constant mixed higher order mean curvatures. As applications of those Alexandrov theorems. These theorems are useful to construct a foliation for spacetimes, with certain good properties. This construction will provide a nice geometric characterization for the center of mass of spacelike submanifolds.

The research funded by this grant has resulted in several publications in leading international mathematical journals, dissemination of the research findings at international conferences, workshops and seminars at Universities, training of graduate students through informal reading seminars and graduate courses and collaboration with mathematicians at institutions in the US and abroad.
